rulesPage.title: English Article Rules
rulesPage.subtitle: Master the usage of "a", "an", "the", and when to use no article at all. Click on any rule card to see detailed explanations and examples.
rulesPage.tryAdjusting: Try adjusting your search terms or filters

definite-specific.title: The Definite Article "THE" - Specific Items
definite-specific.description: Use "the" when referring to something specific that both the speaker and listener know about.
definite-specific.explanation: When we use "the," we assume the listener knows exactly which item we're talking about. This could be because it was mentioned before, is visible, or is unique in the context.
examples: The book on the table is mine.
The car in the garage needs repair.
The teacher you mentioned is very kind.

definite-unique.title: The Definite Article "THE" - Unique Items
definite-unique.description: Use "the" with things that are unique or one of a kind.
definite-unique.explanation: Some things are naturally unique - there's only one sun, one moon, one president of a country at a time. These always take "the."
examples: The sun is shining brightly.
The moon looks beautiful tonight.
The President announced new policies.

definite-superlatives.title: The Definite Article "THE" - Superlatives
definite-superlatives.explanation: Superlatives (best, worst, most beautiful, etc.) describe the extreme of a quality, making the noun unique, so they always need "the."
examples: She is the smartest student in class.
This is the most expensive car.
He ran the fastest in the race.

indefinite-first-mention.title: Indefinite Articles "A/AN" - First Mention
indefinite-first-mention.description: Use "a" or "an" when mentioning something for the first time or when it doesn't matter which specific one.
indefinite-first-mention.explanation: When introducing something new to the conversation or when any example of that thing will do, we use "a" or "an." Use "a" before consonant sounds and "an" before vowel sounds. Remember: it's about the sound, not the letter - "an hour" (vowel sound) vs "a university" (consonant sound).
examples: I saw a dog in the park. (consonant sound)
She bought an apple at the store. (vowel sound)
He needs a new computer. (consonant sound)
It was an honest mistake. (vowel sound - silent h)

indefinite-jobs-professions.title: Indefinite Articles "A/AN" - Jobs and Professions
indefinite-jobs-professions.description: Use "a" or "an" when talking about someone's job or profession.
indefinite-jobs-professions.explanation: When describing what someone does for work, we use the indefinite article because there are many people with that profession. Use "a" before consonant sounds and "an" before vowel sounds.
examples: She is a teacher. (consonant sound)
He wants to become an engineer. (vowel sound)
My father is a doctor. (consonant sound)
I am an artist. (vowel sound)

no-article-general.title: No Article - General Statements
no-article-general.description: Don't use articles when making general statements about uncountable nouns or plural countable nouns.
no-article-general.explanation: When talking about things in general (not specific examples), we often don't use articles. This applies to uncountable nouns (water, music) and plural countable nouns (dogs, people).
examples: Water is essential for life.
Dogs are loyal animals.
Music makes people happy.

no-article-proper-nouns.title: No Article - Proper Nouns
no-article-proper-nouns.description: Most proper nouns (names of people, places, etc.) don't use articles.
no-article-proper-nouns.explanation: Names of people, most cities, countries, companies, and universities don't need articles because they are already specific by nature.
examples: London is a beautiful city.
Mary works at Microsoft.
I study at Harvard University.

definite-geographic.title: The Definite Article "THE" - Geographic Features
definite-geographic.description: Use "the" with oceans, seas, rivers, mountain ranges, and groups of islands.
definite-geographic.explanation: Certain geographic features traditionally take "the," especially bodies of water, mountain ranges, and island groups. However, individual mountains and lakes usually don't.
examples: The Pacific Ocean is huge.
The Nile River flows through Egypt.
The Himalayas are the highest mountains.

gameSentences.1: Use 'the' because we're referring to a specific table that both speaker and listener know about.
gameSentences.2: Use 'the' because it refers to a specific book that was previously mentioned.
gameSentences.3: Use 'the' because it's a specific window that both people can see or know about.
gameSentences.4: Use 'the' because there is only one sun - it's unique.
gameSentences.5: Use 'the' because there is only one President at a time in a country.
gameSentences.6: Use 'the' because there is only one Earth - it's unique.
gameSentences.7: Use 'the' with superlatives like 'best' because they describe the ultimate example.
gameSentences.8: Use 'the' with superlatives like 'tallest' - there can only be one tallest person.
gameSentences.9: Use 'the' with superlatives like 'most difficult' to indicate the extreme example.
gameSentences.10: Use 'a/an' when mentioning something for the first time. Use 'an' because 'interesting' starts with a vowel sound.
gameSentences.11: Use 'a/an' when mentioning something for the first time. Use 'a' because 'new' starts with a consonant sound.
gameSentences.12: Use 'a/an' when introducing something new to the conversation. Use 'a' because 'cat' starts with a consonant sound.
gameSentences.13: Use 'a/an' with professions. Use 'a' because 'nurse' starts with a consonant sound.
gameSentences.14: Use 'a/an' with professions. Use 'an' because 'architect' starts with a vowel sound.
gameSentences.15: Use 'a/an' with professions. Use 'a' because 'teacher' starts with a consonant sound.
gameSentences.16: No article needed when making general statements about uncountable nouns like 'water'.
gameSentences.17: No article needed when making general statements about plural countable nouns like 'dogs'.
gameSentences.18: No article needed when making general statements about uncountable nouns like 'music'.
gameSentences.19: No article needed with most city names - they are proper nouns.
gameSentences.20: No article needed with company names - they are proper nouns.
gameSentences.21: No article needed with people's names - they are proper nouns.
gameSentences.22: Use 'the' with rivers - they are specific geographic features.
gameSentences.23: Use 'the' with oceans - they are specific geographic features.
gameSentences.24: Use 'the' with mountain ranges - they are specific geographic features.
gameSentences.25: Use 'the' because it refers to the specific salt container on the table that both people can see.
gameSentences.26: Use 'a/an' when mentioning something for the first time. Use 'an' because 'umbrella' starts with a vowel sound.
gameSentences.27: No article needed when making general statements about uncountable nouns like 'coffee'.
gameSentences.28: Use 'the' with superlatives like 'worst' - it describes the most extreme example.
gameSentences.29: Use 'a/an' with professions. Use 'an' because 'engineer' starts with a vowel sound.
